thread.title: Alternatives to the Dover-Calais ferry

author: Oliver Smith
title: Alternatives to the Dover-Calais ferry
text:
Comments 
So near and yet so far. Calais may be just 26 miles from Dover, but northern France’s main port seems considerably more distant at the moment – made less accessible by a combination of striking ferry workers and migrants seeking to reach Britain, which has caused the cancellation of cross-Channel services, long delays and tailbacks of lorries on the M20. 
If you have yet to book, don't despair, there are alternative ways to cross the Channel. 
Protestors burn tyres near Calais Photo: GETTY By sea 
It is worth underlining that ferries are still running from Dover to Calais. Both P&O Ferries (0800 130 0030; poferries.com ) and DFDS (01304 874158; dfdsseaways.co.uk ) are sailing between the ports. Both companies’ websites and Twitter feeds ( @Poferriesupdate ; @dfdsukupdates ) provide regular updates on the travel situation. 
However, if you wish to avoid Calais entirely, you have a choice of alternative ports. Dunkirk, 30 miles north-east of Calais, is the next best thing – accessible through DFDS. 
Depending on your destination in France, Normandy may be a plausible point of arrival. 
• Ferries to France: cheap fares and route details 
Brittany Ferries (0871 244 1400; brittanyferries.com ) links Portsmouth to Le Havre in just under four hours via catamaran, and in 5½ hours on its conventional ferries. The same operator sails from Portsmouth to Caen in six hours, from Poole to Cherbourg in 4½, and from Portsmouth to Cherbourg via a three-hour fast service. 
Condor Ferries (0845 609 1024; condorferries.co.uk ) crosses from Portsmouth to Cherbourg in seven hours. DFDS, meanwhile, connects Newhaven and Dieppe in four.
